Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Ultra Minimally Invasive Surgical Tools
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project impacts public health by providing small and versatile surgical instruments. These new tools, and the business models that facilitate wide deployment of them, have the potential to yield substantial public health impact. The tools will enable surgeons to perform surgery through needle-sized openings in the human body rather than large incisions. This will result in faster patient recovery and less pain. Also, less invasive surgeries should be expected to reduce hospitalization time and thus produce substantial financial savings for the national health care system. This I-Corps project will investigate the use of these new instruments in sinus surgery, eye surgery, and neurosurgery, among other clinical applications. Each of these are large potential markets for the technology.

This I-Corps project is based on prior NSF-funded discovery that superelastic flexure elements can enable ultra-miniature deflectable surgical tools. The invention that forms the basis of this I-Corps project involves selective removal of material from a superelastic Nitinol tube to create an articulated instrument tip. This was motivated by the need for very small-diameter (needle-size) robot wrists. A goal of this I-Corps project is to determine whether it can be used in non-robotic hand-held surgical instruments to help surgeons access hard-to-reach locations in the human body (e.g. the sinus cavities or the ventricles in the brain). The I-Corps process will be used to determine whether customers prefer this device as a robotic system or as a non-motorized hand-held tool. It will also be used to determine which user interface is desired by surgeons in each surgical specialty, as well as which tip shapes are most valuable in each surgical procedure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this I-Corps project we explored the question: What if surgery could be done through openings so small that a simple Band-Aid could close the wound? We believed going into the project that this would help patients would have no scars, less pain, and shorter hospital stays. Our invention - a novel bendable tip design - enables surgical tools to be small enough that this is possible, yet also makes them capable of complex movements. Our goal through I-Corps was to validate a business model for the technology so that it could progress out from the academic research lab where it was created into the medical device world, and thus get into the hands of physicians to help their patients. Through our I-Corps project we explored many medical markets including Neurosurgery, Eye Surgery, Ear Nose and Throat (ENT) Surgery, Urologic Surgery, as well as delving into what features were needed on our product to make it a minimum viable product that was as straightforward as possible to manufacture and deploy.  We interviewed many potential customers and developed a business model for our device in collaboration with the I-Corps instructional staff. The Intellectual Merit in our project consisted of: (1) obtaining a better understanding of the characteristics of miniature articulated tools necessary for their use in various surgical procedures, (2) identifying key product features desired by clinicians within such a tool, (3) the creation and characterization of a deflectable tool prototype for at least one specific surgical intervention, (4) and the formulation of a business model suitable for delivering to physicians a viable product based on their needs and the needs of patients.  The Broader Impacts in our project related to improving public health. Successful creation of systems and business models that enable surgeons to do surgeries through needle-sized openings can yield faster patient recovery and less pain. Also importantly, less invasive surgeries should be expected to reduce hospitalization duration, and thus result in substantial financial savings for the health care system.
